request_pathways.name: Authorization for Release of Protected Health Information (English)
Autorización para la Divulgación de Información de Salud Protegida (Spanish)
Fax submission to Health Information Management
Mail submission to DHR Health HIM Department

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient downloads a generic bidirectional HIPAA authorization form, fills it out, and submits by fax or mail to the Health Information Management department.

red_flags: Social Security Number requested with no indication it is optional
Purpose field required without noting HIPAA Right of Access exemption
Liability waiver bundled into authorization on Spanish form
Form dated August 2015 — over a decade old, predating 21st Century Cures Act
bright_spots: Bilingual (English and Spanish) forms available for Rio Grande Valley population
Granular record type selection with ~20 checkbox categories
Medical Records page easy to find — 2 clicks from homepage

findability.rationale: Level 4: Easy to find with basic navigation — Medical Records page is 2 clicks from homepage with clearly labeled download links, though legacy URLs from CMS migration return empty files.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 3: Usable digitally with workarounds; fax submission available — English form has fillable fields (unnamed) and text layer but is not digital-first; Spanish version is an image-only scan with no text layer.

content_design.rationale: Level 3: Adequate but notable problems — bidirectional OR structure is confusing, psychiatric consent section is dense and ambiguous, but form is 2 pages with reasonable record type checklist.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 2: Patient self-access is not addressed — form is a generic third-party release authorization with no Right of Access language, no patient rights statement, and requires purpose justification HIPAA does not mandate.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: Requirements that go beyond what the law requires — SSN collection, purpose field without exemption, liability waiver in Spanish version, witness requirement, no fee disclosure, and no patient rights information.

overall.summary: DHR Health provides an easily findable but outdated generic release form that makes no accommodation for patient self-access, requires unnecessary personal information, and has significant quality gaps between its English and Spanish versions.
